title: Targeted Sequencing by Sanger to Recover Key Mutations in Illumina SARS-CoV-2 Whole-genome Sequences
title_html: Targeted Sequencing by Sanger to Recover Key Mutations in Illumina SARS-CoV-2 Whole-genome Sequences

On ice, prepare a master mix containing the components from Table 1 (add 10% extra for pipetting overage).

In a 96-well plate, add 10 μl of master mix to each sample and no-template control (NTC) well.
Add 10 μl of extracted RNA to each sample well. Mix gently by pipetting
Add 10 μl nuclease-free water to the NTC well. Mix gently by pipetting
Seal the 96-well plate and briefly centrifuge the plate to collect the contents at the bottom of the wells.

Place the 96-well plate on a thermocycler and run the PCR condition from Table 3.
Table 3 – One-step Thermocycling Conditions
StepTemperature (°C)Time Cycles
UNG incubation252 minutes1
RT incubation5015 minutes1
Enzyme activation952 minutes1
Amplification953 seconds40
6030 seconds
Hold4

StepTemperature (°C)Time Cycles

6030 seconds
Hold4
PCR Purification
In a new 96-well plate, add 10 µl of the PCR product to 4 µl Exo-SAP IT express reagent on ice.
Mix by gentle pipetting, seal the plate and briefly centrifuge to collect the contents at the bottom of the wells.

Run the following thermocycling conditions (Table 4).
Table 4 - Exo-SAP Express IT Thermocycling conditions

Heat deactivation801 minutes
Hold4hold

Cycle sequencing

On ice, prepare a master mix according to the components in Table 5, for each forward and reverse primer.
Table 5 - BigDye™ Terminator cycle sequencing reaction
ComponentVolume (μl)
BigDye™ Terminator 3.1 Ready Reaction Mix2
BigDye™ Terminator v1.1 & v3.1 5X Sequencing Buffer1
501Y.V2 forward OR reverse (3.2uM)1
Nuclease-free water 5
Total volume9ul

Table 5 - BigDye™ Terminator cycle sequencing reaction
ComponentVolume (μl)

BigDye™ Terminator v1.1 & v3.1 5X Sequencing Buffer1
501Y.V2 forward OR reverse (3.2uM)1
Nuclease-free water 5
Total volume9ul
Add 9 µl of cycle sequencing master mix to each sample / NTC well of a 96-well plate.
Add 1 µl of purified PCR product to each well.
Mix gently by pipetting.

Prepare an internal positive pGEM control by mixing the components from Table 6 and adding to a designated well of the 96-well plate.
Table 6 – pGEM internal control reaction volume
ComponentVolume (μl)
BigDye™ Terminator 3.1 Ready Reaction Mix4
M13 (-21) Primer2
pGEM Control DNA1
Deionized water3
Total volume10

Seal the plate, briefly centrifuge and place the plate in a thermocycler to run the conditions from Table 7.

Cycle sequencing reaction purification

Using the BigDye Xterminator Purification kit, prepare a master mix according to the volumes in Table 8. Prepare an additional 10% for pipetting overage.
Table 8 – BigDye XTerminator Mastermix
ComponentVol x1 (µl)
SAM solution45
XTerminator Solution10
Total55

Table 8 – BigDye XTerminator Mastermix
ComponentVol x1 (µl)
SAM solution45
XTerminator Solution10
Total55
Ensure that the solution is properly mixed and add 55 µl to each well.
Seal the plate and vortex at 1800 rpm for 30 minutes.
Centrifuge the plate at 1000 xg for 2 minutes.
Proceed with capillary electrophoresis on a DNA sequencer.

description:
The Spike (S) gene of SARS-CoV-2 demonstrates more frequent mutations in an otherwise conserved genome. With the proliferation of SARS-CoV-2 variants, there is an urgent need to continuously monitor the novel mutations arising to investigate viral diversity and vaccine escape mutants. Next-generation sequencing (NGS) technologiesthat are predominantly used to generate whole-genome sequences due to cost-effectiveness are prone to insufficient coverage and gaps in the sequence products. Sanger sequencing technology presents a complementary solution to enhance NGS sequencing through quick, gene-specific sequencing that has the potential to mitigate or avoid some of these challenges. Here we present sequencing primers that we designed and an associated workflow to recover key mutations (K417N, E484K, N501Y) in the receptor-binding domain of the 501Y.V2 lineage recently identified in South Africa.
The Sanger sequencing CE workflow
